results.abstract: Article in series The Crew profiles Japanese astronaut Soichi Noguchi and explains his role in mission of space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for launch on July 13; Noguchi will photograph external fuel tank as it separates from orbiter and falls away; this is part of testing solutions that NASA developed in aftermath of Columbia accident (M)

headline.main: For Japanese Astronaut, the Wait Is Almost Over

results.snippet: Japan's sixth astronaut will play a central role in testing the solutions that NASA has developed in the aftermath of the loss of the shuttle Columbia two years ago.
results.lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Discovery is launched, Soichi Noguchi will begin to work quickly. Two minutes after the main engines cut off, he will pull out a camcorder and a digital camera to take pictures of the external fuel tank as it separates from the orbiter and falls away. Mr. Noguchi, who will be Japan's sixth astronaut, has been waiting for the launching. now set for July 13, for four years, when he was assigned to the mission, STS-114. Originally, his main task was to bolt pieces onto the International Space Station. Now he will play a central role in testing the solutions that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has developed in the aftermath of the loss of the shuttle Columbia two years ago.

headline.main: Taking a Bit Of New York Into Space

results.snippet: Charles J. Camarda has something you usually do not expect from a NASA astronaut: a New York mouth. Not just the accent, but also the attitude.
results.lead_paragraph: Charles J. Camarda has something you usually do not expect from a NASA astronaut: a New York mouth. Not just the accent, but also the attitude. An aerospace engineer who holds seven patents, Dr. Camarda grew up in the Ozone Park section of Queens, near Aqueduct Racetrack, a boy who played stickball in the streets and later proved his mettle in the boxing ring.

headline.main: As Shuttle Returns, Emotions Tug Columbia Families Anew

results.snippet: Families of Columbia crew members find themselves dealing differently with the launch of the Discovery planned for Wednesday.
results.lead_paragraph: Among the most surreal moments of the last two and a half years for Lani McCool and Rona Ramon, whose husbands died when the space shuttle Columbia broke apart, was a vacation together in the Seattle area last week. There were no memorial services or dedications, no speeches to give, no pressure to be a national ''symbol of strength,'' as Mrs. Ramon said. It was just the two friends, ''soul mates'' in their words, sipping bowls of cappuccino, building a campfire in the woods, talking quietly about raising children alone, or not talking at all. Over dessert one night, Mrs. Ramon, the widow of Col. Ilan Ramon, the first Israeli astronaut to go into space, turned to Mrs. McCool, the widow of Cmdr. William C. McCool, the Columbia's pilot, and said, ''They were the best.''

headline.main: Basso and CSC Are Only Spinning Wheels

results.snippet: The American multinational company CSC, which once subsidized its own astronaut in outer space, is now sinking serious money into Ivan Basso and cycling.
results.lead_paragraph: IT'S over. Been over for days, ever since Lance Armstrong aced the Pyrenees on Sunday. The only thing that can stop him now is jealousy-induced vertigo. ''You could fall off and break a collarbone,'' Armstrong said the other day. ''Tour over.''

results.abstract: Article in series The Crew, on astronauts of space shuttle Discovery, profiles Col James M Kelly of Air Force, who will pilot mission (M)

headline.main: A Confident Pilot With an Eye for Detail

results.snippet: Col. James M. Kelly of the Air Force has logged more than 3,000 hours in various types of aircraft. Flying a shuttle, he says, is not all that different.
results.lead_paragraph: Col. James M. Kelly of the Air Force has logged more than 3,000 hours in F-15 fighters and 35 other types of aircraft. Flying the shuttle, he says, is not all that different. ''The real preparation from flying airplanes is making quick decisions in critical environments,'' he said. ''Your life depends on making the right decision at the right time. And also your life depends on maybe deciding to do nothing at that point.''

results.abstract: Article in series The Crew, on astronauts of space shuttle Discovery, profiles Capt Wendy B Lawrence of Navy, who will make her fourth career trip on coming flight; she is responsible for transferring much-needed supplies to International Space Station (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Specialist Expects a Busy Mission

results.snippet: The flight of the shuttle Discovery will be Captain Wendy B. Lawrence's fourth career trip. It is not expected to be relaxing.
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Wendy B. Lawrence of the Navy looks at her first space shuttle flight in 1995 almost as a vacation. ''I'm like, wow, what a great deal I had,'' Captain Lawrence said in an interview in April. ''Sixteen days in space.''

headline.main: Soon in Space: Repair Work, Some Walks And Music

results.snippet: Stephen K. Robinson is an astronaut who tries to combine his love of flying with the worlds of music and art.
results.lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Robinson is an astronaut who tries to combine his love of flying with the worlds of music and art. A 49-year-old mechanical engineer, Dr. Robinson shrugs off any reference to his being a Renaissance man, saying he is just a curious person. His interests include aerodynamics and flying, eye movement research, antique aircraft, swimming, graphic design, painting, stereo photography and all types of music.

headline.main: From Rocket Science to Political Science to a Primary Victory

results.snippet: IT'S not that Jun Choi, the surprise winner of a fierce Democratic mayoral primary in Edison, isn't proud of his Korean heritage.      It's just that, even though he has received scores of interview requests from the Korean-language news media and...
results.lead_paragraph: IT'S not that Jun Choi, the surprise winner of a fierce Democratic mayoral primary in Edison, isn't proud of his Korean heritage. It's just that, even though he has received scores of interview requests from the Korean-language news media and has become something of a celebrity in Seoul, Mr. Choi doesn't consider his ethnicity to be the most significant aspect of his accomplishment.

results.abstract: Age-related complaints abound about space shuttle Discovery as it prepares to lift off on first shuttle mission since loss of Columbia two and half years ago; NASA says age alone is not bar to successful or safe flight; photo (M)

headline.main: As NASA Prepares to Launch Shuttles Again, 70's-Era Technology Is Showing Its Age

results.snippet: Like an increasingly creaky baby boomer who can still run a marathon, the space shuttle is a delicate organism that can do miraculous things. But as the Discovery prepares to lift off Tuesday morning on the first shuttle mission since the loss of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Like an increasingly creaky baby boomer who can still run a marathon, the space shuttle is a delicate organism that can do miraculous things. But as the Discovery prepares to lift off Tuesday morning on the first shuttle mission since the loss of the Columbia two and a half years ago, it is clearly feeling its age. The launching is scheduled for 10:39 a.m. Tuesday, but the question of malfunctioning fuel level sensors is still hanging over the process.

headline.kicker: RETURN TO SPACE: THE NEWS MEDIA
headline.main: A Familiar Televised Ritual: Watching, Marveling and, Finally, Exhaling

results.lead_paragraph: We watch to make sure nothing bad happens. A space launching may be the only event that is watched for just one reason, and yesterday, as the networks hurriedly replaced ''The Tony Danza Show'' and ''Guiding Light'' with retired NASA engineers and blinking countdown clocks, a familiar television ritual took place. The nation watched, worried and then finally, at 10:39 a.m., gaped, marveling at the sight of the shuttle Discovery defying gravity with a stately power and grace that never grows old because it never seems certain. Space has been the new frontier for almost half a century, yet still, at each launching, viewers wonder whether, this time, it will work.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery lifts off from Cape Canaveral, carrying seven astronauts on 12 1/2-day mission to resupply International Space Station and also to demonstrate NASA's commitment to safety since loss of Columbia; photos; launch into startlingly blue sky on column of fire and smoke is milestone for agency that has struggled to find and fix problems that cost lives of seven astronauts in 2003; experts study two apparent images of objects falling away during ascent but overall mood is high and astronauts sound jubilant as they soar high above Earth; commander is retired Col Eileen M Collins; spacewalks and other planned activities outlined; diagram (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Roars Back to Space After 2 1/2-Year Absence

results.snippet: With a stuttering roar that shook the air for miles around, the shuttle Discovery lifted off on Tuesday morning.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and WARREN E. LEARY; Simon Romero contributed reporting from Houston for this article

multimedia.credit: Astronauts Stephen K. Robinson and Eileen Collins on the flight deck of the shuttle Discovery.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Astronauts Stephen K. Robinson and Eileen Collins on the flight deck of the shuttle Discovery.

multimedia.credit: The Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex was filled with spectators as the shuttle lifted off.

legacy.MultimediaSummary3: The Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex was filled with spectators as the shuttle lifted off.

results.lead_paragraph: With a stuttering roar that shook the air for miles around, the shuttle Discovery lifted off on Tuesday morning, carrying seven astronauts on a 12 1/2-day mission to resupply the International Space Station and to try to demonstrate NASA's renewed commitment to safety. The launching, at 10:39:00 into a startlingly blue sky, was a milestone for the space agency, which has struggled for two and a half years to find and fix the problems that caused the loss of the shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven astronauts on Feb. 1, 2003.

results.abstract: Discovery's 12 1/2-day mission into space will be one of most photographed in history of shuttle program, with all eyes on craft to see if it suffers kind of damage from blastoff debris that brought down Columbia in 2003; monitoring cameras everywhere may be mixed blessing because more damage engineers look for the more they will find, risking overreaction that could also be dangerous; astronaut Dr David Wolf warns about difficult decisions about damage that could be either critical or inconsequential; diagram (M)

headline.main: Intense Hunt for Signs of Damage Could Raise Problems of Its Own

results.snippet: With NASA watching for signs of damage, Discovery's mission will be the most photographed in shuttle program history.

multimedia.caption: The Discovery Lifts Off
multimedia.credit: The launching was a milestone for NASA, which has struggled to fix problems with the shuttle program.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: The launching was a milestone for NASA, which has struggled to fix problems with the shuttle program.

multimedia.caption: The Return to Space: Discovery's Liftoff
multimedia.credit: Video of the first nine minutes of the shuttle Discovery's successful launch into space.

legacy.MultimediaHeadline3: The Return to Space: Discovery's Liftoff
legacy.MultimediaSummary3: Video of the first nine minutes of the shuttle Discovery's successful launch into space.

results.lead_paragraph: Now that the Discovery is in orbit, the examination begins. Its 12 1/2-day mission will be the most photographed in the history of the shuttle program, with all eyes on the craft to see if it suffered the kind of damage from blastoff debris that brought down the Columbia in February 2003. There were cameras on the launching pad, cameras aloft on planes monitoring the ascent, cameras on the shuttle checking for missing foam on the external fuel tank, and a camera on the tank itself. One camera caught a mysterious object falling from the shuttle at liftoff; radar detected another, about two minutes into the flight. Cameras aboard the shuttle and the International Space Station will monitor the Discovery until the end of its mission.

results.abstract: Article in series The Crew profiles Andrew S W Thomas, Australian engineer who is one of seven astronauts aboard Discovery (M)

headline.main: A Veteran of the Space Program, Working on the Ground and in Outer Space

results.snippet: For every astronaut who goes up into orbit, another astronaut on the ground serves as NASA's liaison to the family.
results.lead_paragraph: For every astronaut who goes up into orbit, another astronaut on the ground serves as NASA's liaison to the family. Andrew S.W. Thomas, an Australian engineer who is one of seven astronauts aboard the Discovery, was the head liaison to the families of the astronauts who died two years ago on the Columbia.

results.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; novelists John Irving, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who will participate in Library of Congress's fifth annual National Book Festival on September 24; photo (S)

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; Writers Celebrate the Book

results.snippet: The Library of Congress has announced that the novelists John Irving, below, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who have agreed to participate in the fifth annual National Book Festival on Sept. 24. The all-day event will...

byline.original: By JOHN FILES; Compiled by Lawrence Van Gelder

results.lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress has announced that the novelists John Irving, below, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who have agreed to participate in the fifth annual National Book Festival on Sept. 24. The all-day event will have as it host Laura Bush, who organized a similar event in Texas when President Bush was governor of that state. Authors will read and discuss their works at seven themed pavilions: Fiction and Fantasy, Mysteries and Thrillers, History and Biography, Children, Teens and Children, Poetry, and Home and Family. Among the writers scheduled to give readings and sign books are the astronaut Buzz Aldrin, the presidential biographer David McCullough, E.L. Doctorow, Tom Clancy and Sandra Brown. R.W. Apple Jr., Thomas L. Friedman and David Brooks of The New York Times will also appear. Discussions and readings from the History and Biography pavilion will be broadcast live from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on C-SPAN2, the library said. (The program will be shown again at 8 p.m.) JOHN FILES

headline.main: For NASA, Misjudgments Led to Latest Shuttle Woes

results.snippet: In hindsight, it is clear that potential problems with fuel tank foam were played down over the life of the shuttle program.

byline.original: This article was reported by John Schwartz, Andrew C. Revkin and Matthew L. Wald and written by Mr. Schwartz

results.lead_paragraph: ''We are ready to fly.'' It was June 24, and William W. Parsons, NASA's shuttle program manager, was speaking to reporters on a telephone conference call from the Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral, Fla. Two and a half years of study and struggle, he told them, were over at long last. The shuttle Discovery could blast off in July.
